Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Improving the recruitment and persistence of women in the Geosciences: Exploring deliberate mentoring approaches aimed at undergraduate students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Women continue to be largely under-represented in the geosciences. Female role models and mentors can play an important role in the lives of female students, especially when choosing and committing to a career path. This project is providing a pathway for STEM undergraduate women into the geosciences through a combination of formal and informal, professional and peer mentoring. The research is also providing insight into why mentoring is beneficial to STEM women. This project recruits first-year college women interested in the geosciences (from any STEM major) from institutions in two geographic regions: the Front Range of Colorado and the Carolinas. During their first year, these women are invited to a regional mentoring workshop to i) learn more about geoscience careers, ii) meet peers with similar academic interests, iii) gain better self-awareness of their values, strengths, and abilities for a career in the geosciences, and iv) expand their psychological, social and institutional resources for a career in the geosciences. After the workshop, the program participants have access to peer mentoring and resources through a web platform. Through this platform, they are able to interact with each other via discussion forums. In addition, they have access to in-person mentoring with female role models via scheduled get-togethers at each institution. The research is focused on quantifying i) the impact of the workshops and mentoring on participants' intentions and behaviors related to geoscience career choices, ii) the impact of the workshops and mentoring on the skills and resources participants use to overcome career-related barriers, and iii) the key features of the workshops and mentoring strategies that predict positive changes in participants' perceptions of and beliefs about the geosciences.

Experimental research on the effectiveness of mentoring has been largely absent from the mentoring literature. This project will fill the gap in the literature by conducting a randomized experiment wherein undergraduate women at Colorado State University and the University of North Carolina at Charlotte will be matched based on their initial interest in geosciences, academic record, and demographic characteristics. Matched pairs will be randomly assigned to intervention (workshop and mentoring) or control conditions. Thereafter, women in both groups will participate in a biannual web-based survey with questions concerning their identification with math, their sense of potential fulfillment in careers in the sciences in general and geosciences specifically, their gender stereotypes of the geosciences, and their experiences with mentors. In addition, interviews will be conducted with the women in the intervention group to examine supports and challenges, and the role of the intervention in their interest and/or persistence in geoscience educations and careers. Dissemination of results will be accomplished through publication in peer-reviewed journals and presentations at professional meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project recruited STEM undergraduate women to nurture their interest and persistence in the geosciences through mentoring, role models, and education. We developed PROGRESS (PROmoting Geoscience Research, Education, and SuccesS), a program that provides professional development workshops, access to female mentors and role models, and online discussions and resources. Our professional development workshops connected undergraduate women to more senior women in the geosciences, established connections between the students (on individual campuses and regionally), helped students identify role models and the value of mentoring, and provided training in resiliency strategies. Following the workshops, students were given access to a website and a closed Facebook group where they shared opportunities and asked questions of their peer network.

In Years 2 and 3 of the project, we recruited first- and second-year undergraduate STEM women with an interest in the geosciences to participate in the study. In Year 2, we recruited women from four universities in the Colorado/Wyoming Front Range (Colorado College, Colorado State University (CSU), University of Colorado Boulder (CU-Boulder), & University of Wyoming) and three universities in the Carolinas (North Carolina State University (NC State), University of North Carolina - Charlotte (UNC-Charlotte), University of South Carolina (USC)). In Year 3, the project team expanded the regional network of schools (Front Range: Metropolitan State University of Denver (Metro State); Carolinas: North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NCAT)). Study participants either participated in the PROGRESS intervention or were members of a propensity score matched sample of highly similar women that did not participate (i.e., the control group). Following the PROGRESS workshops, we organized 50+ in-person group mentoring (local and regional) and networking events (ranging from coffee, to volunteer activities in local schools, to career panels), as well as national virtual events focused on how to submit successful applications to summer research experiences (REUs), how to apply to graduate school, and how to build a resume.  

Our research has provided evidence of three clear benefits for women in PROGRESS. 1) PROGRESS helps women grow their mentoring support and inspirational role modeling networks. Compared to women in the matched control group, women in PROGRESS develop larger networks of STEM mentors, are more likely to have a faculty mentor, and report having more female STEM career role models. 2) The benefits of PROGRESS compound to support women’s interest and persistence in geosciences. Compared to women in the control group, women in PROGRESS exhibited higher scientific career intentions, developed deeper interest in the geosciences, and had higher rates of persistence in a geoscience major because of the involvement in PROGRESS and identification of inspirational female STEM career role models. 3) PROGRESS “works” because it helps women develop a stronger sense of scientific identity. PROGRESS has beneficial effects on interest and persistence because women in PROGRESS and women with mentors develop stronger scientific identities.

In Year 5, we conducted the final two follow-up surveys with all study participants. Our long-term follow-up through the senior year of college indicates that women in PROGRESS were 5.5-times more likely to persist in a geoscience major (94.7% vs. 76.3% persistence rate) and 2.5-times more likely to persist in any STEM major (91.7% vs. 81.4% persistence rate), compared the control group.

 

We received supplemental funding in Year 5 with the goal to increase the scalability of PROGRESS by identifying its essential elements. We conducted a randomized experiment to identify the elements required to promote mentoring, motivation, and resilience outcomes linked to undergraduate women’s long-term persistence in the geosciences. We recruited 158 undergraduate women pursuing a geoscience degree from 10 universities to participate in a 1-day PROGRESS professional development workshop. We systematically varied the workshop content and post-workshop experiences from the least to the most resource intensive support and randomly assigned women to 1-of-3 groups: (a) exposure to geoscience careers via female career role models, but no post-workshop interactions (“Inspiration” group); (b) geoscience career role modeling and training on how to grow their network of mentoring relationships and overcome obstacles to scientific careers, but no post-workshop interactions (“Inspiration & Inoculation” group); or (c) geoscience career role modeling, mentee and resilience training with a post-workshop introduction to a local female geoscience mentor (“Inspiration, Inoculation, & Introduction” group). Only women in the “Inspiration, Inoculation, & Introduction” group experienced significant growth in their network of mentors, which, in turn, led to higher scientific identity, resilience skills, and intentions to persist in scientific careers.

In summary, our longitudinal quasi-experimental and randomized experimental studies show that the PROGRESS intervention causes growth in the development of stronger networks of mentors and role models, which in turn, promotes growth in critical psychological processes (i.e., mediators), such as scientific identity. These critical psychological processes promote growth in skills to cope with barriers to scientific careers, intentions to pursue a scientific career, and actual persistence in degree pathways.
